data.file-reading-functions#File Reading Func:
fopen() Opens a file and returns a file pointer to it.
FILE *fopen(const char *filename, const char *mode); Return Value:
Success: Pointer to FILE Error: NULL Example:
FILE *fp = fopen("example.txt", "r"); fclose() Closes a previously opened file stream.
int fclose(FILE *stream); n Return Value:
Success: 0 Error: EOF Example:
fclose(fp); fgets() Reads a string from a file, stopping at newline or EOF.
char *fgets(char *str, int n, FILE *stream); Return Value:
Success: str Error or EOF: NULL Example:
char line[256]; fgets(line, sizeof line, fp); fgetc() Reads a single character from a file.
int fgetc(FILE *stream); Return Value:
Success: Character as an unsigned char cast to int Error or EOF: EOF Example:
int ch = fgetc(fp); // returns int, not char fread() Reads binary data from a file stream.
size_t fread(void *ptr, size_t size, size_t count, FILE *stream); Return Value:
Number of full elements successfully read Example:
int block[512]; size_t n = fread(block, 1, sizeof block, fp); fscanf() Reads formatted input from a file stream.
int fscanf(FILE *stream, const char *format, ...); Return Value:
Number of items successfully read and assigned EOF if input failure occurs before any conversion Example:
int x, y; fscanf(fp, "%d %d", &x, &y); feof() Checks whether the end-of-file indicator is set.
int feof(FILE *stream); Return Value:
Non-zero if EOF indicator is set 0 otherwise Example:
if (feof(fp)) { /* reached end-of-file */ } ferror() Checks whether a file stream has an error.
int ferror(FILE *stream); Return Value:
Non-zero if an error occurred 0 otherwise Example:
if (ferror(fp)) { /* handle stream error */ }

data.macros#MACROS:
WIFEXITED Returns true if the child terminated normally (via exit() or _exit()).
WIFEXITED(status) Return Value:
True if child terminated normally WEXITSTATUS Returns the exit status code of the child (only valid if WIFEXITED(status) is true).
WEXITSTATUS(status) Return Value:
Return code when WIFEXITED is true WIFSIGNALED Returns true if the child terminated due to an uncaught signal.
WIFSIGNALED(status) Return Value:
True if child terminated by signal WTERMSIG Returns the signal number that caused the child to terminate (only valid if WIFSIGNALED(status) is true).
WTERMSIG(status) Return Value:
Signal number when WIFSIGNALED is true WIFSTOPPED Returns true if the child process is currently stopped, not terminated.
WIFSTOPPED(status) Return Value:
True if child is stopped WSTOPSIG Returns the signal number that caused the child to stop (only valid if WIFSTOPPED(status) is true).
WSTOPSIG(status) Return Value:
Signal number when WIFSTOPPED is true
